newsitem.title: JAPAN: JGBs steady by noon after dip on rate hike report.
newsitem.headline: JGBs steady by noon after dip on rate hike report.

text.p: JGBs were steady in the cash and futures markets at the Tokyo midday on Tuesday, after briefly falling on a local TV report that the Liberal Democratic Party (LDP) will recommend to the Prime Minister by the end of May that the official discount rate (ODR) be raised, traders said.
The key June contract dipped to 124.26 in early trade but recovered to 124.53 by midday. It closed at 124.40 on Monday.
The yield of the benchmark 182nd 10-year cash JGB was at 2.460 percent, unchanged from Monday.
An LDP source later said that there had been no decision yet on whether to recommend an ODR hike to the Prime Minister.

The source admitted, however, that there were calls for an early rate rise within an LDP panel that is due to finalise a report on administrative reform for submission to the Prime Minister as early as the end of this month.

NHK television reported early on Tuesday that the panel will make the recommendation in light of parliamentary passage of a bill to drastically reform Japan's Foreign Exchange and Foreign Trade Control Law. The new law will take effect in April, 1998.
The panel argued that Japan needs to tighten credit to avoid further capital outflows from Japan because the new forex law could accelerate such outflows, NHK said.

Traders said that JGBs could have fallen more steeply on the rate hike report, but losses were limited by traders' reluctance to build fresh positions ahead of a U.S. policy setting Federal Open Market Committee meeting later today and a planned 10-year JGB auction on Wednesday.
